abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability uncertain. The Bank
            performance had mixed results, since identification,
            preparation, and appraisal were satisfactory, but
            supervision was deficient due to a number of weaknesses.
            Inadequate supervision, coupled with unexpected business
            related costs, were conducive to poor administrative
            practices, mostly due to unfamiliarity with Government
            procedures. Likewise, for the borrower's performance,
            being preparation satisfactory, while implementation
            deficient. Reform policies were unclear, and, the perception
            is, that credit resources were rather intended as a
            short-term financing mechanism to cover the
            government's budget constraints. Key lessons include:
            1) The principal failing of this project was the lack of
            government ownership, and commitment to reforms, for, while
            momentum for reform existed at preparation, political
            instability hindered success. 2) In the absence of
            institutional capacity, project design should include
            training for local staff. 3) The Bank should be prepared to
            allocate resources according to each operation's
            particular needs, thus, responsiveness to changing
            situations, would produce positive results, through the
            continuity, and strength of a team approach. 4) In the
            absence of expected outcomes, restructuring should be
            considered, and, the Mid-term Review reinforced to evaluate
            performance in pursuit of those outcomes.
